description: Pre-baked voice clips for FTUE (First-Time User Experience)

clips.script: Welcome to Gas Town. I'm your slightly snarky assistant, and I promise I'm here to help. Mostly.
This is the Refinery Floor - your command center. Convoys on the left, activity on the right. Try not to break anything.
Convoys are batches of work moving through the system. Think of them as road trains hauling your tasks. The progress bars tell you how close you are to done.
Polecats are your worker agents. They're ephemeral - they spawn, do work, and disappear. Like good code reviewers.
A rig is your project container. It has polecats, a merge queue called the refinery, and a witness that makes sure nobody gets stuck.
Beads are your issues - bugs, features, tasks. We track them so you don't have to remember everything. Unlike your brain, we don't forget.
You can talk to me. Just hold the spacebar and ask. Or click the mic button if you're feeling fancy.
The tmux panel shows your terminal sessions. Yes, there's still a command line underneath. Old habits die hard.
To assign work, say 'sling that to' followed by the rig name. Or use the UI if you're into clicking things.
We track costs so you don't accidentally burn through your budget. You can set alerts. I'll nag you. It's what I do.
Lost connection? No worries. I'll cache what I can and sync when you're back online. I'm helpful like that.
Command-K opens the command palette. It's faster than clicking around. Trust me on this one.
The activity feed shows what's happening in real-time. Commits, merges, stuck polecats - all the drama.
The refinery is your merge queue. Work goes in, clean code comes out. Usually.
The witness monitors polecats. If one gets stuck, it nudges them. Think of it as a nervous hall monitor.
Need help? Just ask 'what can you do' or 'help me with' something. I'm snarky, not unhelpful.
That's the basics. You're ready to cause some chaos. Don't worry, I'll be here to judge your code.
